bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: From 1965-1968, the Ford Foundation worked on a goal to ultimately provide free educational television across the United States utilizing satellite technology. On August 1, 1966, the Ford Foundation submitted a statement to the FCC that proposed the creation of a satellite system to serve both noncommercial television (informational, cultural, and instructional) and commercial television. The Foundation consulted Bell Labs and IBM on the feasibility of the project. The Foundation did not seek to own or operate a satellite system, but it was prepared to establish a nonprofit domestic satellite corporation with trustees representing noncommercial and commercial broadcasters, foundations, schools, universities, and government.

The FCC lacked the policy guidelines to fully implement the project and the satellite was never realized. With the goal of promoting free public television, the Foundation announced that it would support the endeavors of the Corporation for Public Broadcasting which was established in 1967 by an act of the United States Congress. The Foundation also created its own Office of Public Broadcasting at this time. The Ford Foundation established the Public Broadcast Laboratory (PBL) for a two-year demonstration of the power of national interconnection for noncommercial television.

The Ford Foundation first made grants in the field of media and communications in 1951, when funds were provided to the Radio and Television Workshop for the production of broadcast programming. Through 1977, the foundation gave over $295 million to develop public television stations, networks and content.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection is composed of reports, correspondence, memos, and contracts that were originally stored in binders for the Ford Foundation's educational satellite project. Materials from the FCC, Howard Dressner, Fred Friendly, McGeorge Bundy, Verne S. Atwater, Richard Catalano of the Ford Foundation and David Ginsburg of the Law Offices of Ginsburg and Feldman are featured throughout the collection.
